title: vj day letter thanks welsh government first minister mark drakeford
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityStan Smith, of Barry, spoke to the deputy minister.Mr Smith was on board ship for VJ day and to this day he remains integral to the work of the Royal British Legion in his hometown, supporting those who have served in the armed forces.MORE STORIESVeterans advice service for Vale ex-service personnel during coronavirus crisisMark the th anniversary of VE Day in the ValeWe will remember themMr Drakeford said: "The surrender of Japan to the Allied forces  years ago, signalled the end of the Second World War."Six years of unprecedented conflict and suffering was finally coming to a close."And the Welsh troops who had been fighting in the Far East and Pacic were toto their beloved homeland once more."I was lucky enough to speak with veterans who served in the Far East during the Second World War over zoom this week."The inspirational stories I heard from Walford Hughes and Ted Owens will stay with me forever, as will their support for fellow veterans readjusting to le after war."Today it is dficult to imagine just how many people were devastated by the legacy of war that raged across this huge expanse of our planet, all the way from Hawaii to India."Tragically, millions of civilians across Asia-Pacic were killed and injured."The first ever nuclear bomb used in war brought devastation to the people of Hiroshima."Its legacy would last for decades to come."Between December  and August , British and Commonwealth forces and their allies engaged in ferocious fighting by land, air and sea, across jungles and remote islands."By the end of the war, , British troops had been killed in the Far East, with three times as many injured."Over , allied troops had suffered brutal conditions as prisoners of war."Those who became prisoners faced harrowing conditions."Some were sent to labour camps in the jungle. Others built roads and bridges."TheBurma-Thailand railway was nicknamed, lsquoDeath Railwayrsquo, after , prisoners of war and , local labourers died constructing its path."The allied civilians living in the Far East were captured and interned in camps, where women, children and men were subjected to similarly brutal conditions."For all those who survived ndash military and civilians - the wounds of war were etched firmly in their psyche for good."After the joy of Victory in Europeday, we can only imagine the courage and fortitude of those who remained at war for another three long months."The Welsh troops serving in the Far East and Pacic faced conditions theyrsquod never even heard of before."In extreme heat, in monsoons, alongside mosquitos and facing tropical disease, their battle was quite extraordinary."Collaboration with allies was key to success. Indian, Myanmarese, Nepali and troops from across the African continent, led the effort in South East Asia with Australian, New Zealand, Pacic Islanders, US and Canadians in the South West and Central Pacic."Many other nations also contributed."Around  per cent of personnel of the main army in South East Asia ndash the th Army - hailed from modern day India, Pakistan and Bangladesh."The contribution of volunteers across the nations was staggering. The Indian Army, had grown to . million members by the end of the war, making it the largest volunteer army in history."After the elation of VE day, some Welsh troops who survived the Far East felt like the lsquoForgotten Armyrsquo."They had served so far away, cut off from their loved ones and any contact with the world they had known."The focus at home had firmly been on Europe they could be forgiven for thinking their efforts had been forgotten."Tragically, many who died were left in those foreign fields, in unmarked graves."On Victory in Japanday, those in the Far East were still overseas, or on board a ship in the middle of the ocean like Stan Smith from Barry, weeks or months from home."Those who ed were changed forever by their experiences."He added: "On Saturday, we will mark this important anniversary and pay tribute to all those affected by the war in the Far East and Pacic: Service personnel, their families and all civilians around the world.       ,params: .push"We pay our tributes to all of those affected by war, in our own extraordinary time, under the shadow of coronavirus, no doubt impacting our usual plans for commemorations."But at a time when we have had to make sacrices and suffered losses, we remember those  years ago who were there at the end of the most destructive conflict the world has ever seen."Those whose sacrice and suffering allowed the next generation to work towards peace."We thank you."We remember you."You will never be forgotten."Get involved:Take part in a two minute silence at am on Saturday, August Celebrate in multi-storey car park on the existing Old Harbour site.Their call follows residents continuing to see visitors parking in streets outside their homes in addition to the knowledge that once the former Butlins Nellrsquos Point site, parking capacity would be reduced.Baruc ward councillor, Steffan Wiliam first suggested the idea in response to parking concerns.He said the Island needs to be lsquofuture-proofedrsquo to cater for increased tourist numbers and ensure minimal disruption for Island residents.MORE STORIESBarry Island residents want to reclaim streets from motorists avoiding parking chargesThirty thousand people flock to Barry Island following hot weather predictionsPesky seagulls, short pier, missing sand, but theres Greggs - Trip Advisors Vale reviewsWhitmore + Jackson cafeacute owner, Dave Lewis said: ldquoBarry Island has a car parking problem because over the years the number of spaces have diminished and ndash with the councilrsquos plan to sell land where the Nellrsquos Point car park at the moment ndash the situation will only get worse.ldquoThatrsquos a great pity because Barry Island is such a fantastic location and - whilst there is a railway and buses ndash people come from further afield and do need parking.ldquoAt the moment we have visitors who overflow into the rest of the Island into the residential areas.ldquoAs well as being a cafeacute owner Irsquom a resident and I can see the problems.ldquoSomething needs to happen at some point to allow Barry Island to continue to grow.ldquoThe proposal for a multi-storey car park is a really good idea.ldquoWhatever is proposed and built is something that fits around Barry Island.ldquoWe donrsquot want an eyesore ndash the first thing that people see is some ugly monstrosity of a car park.ldquoIt would be really goodthere was some sort of multi-purpose construction.ldquoWhatever goes there needs to have some sort of validity as a building as well as a car park.ldquoWhatever is developed needs to provide good value, structured car parking prices.ldquoMost traders on Barry Island would say what wersquove got on Barry Island doesnrsquot really work.ldquoA pound for an hour and pound for the whole of the day and nothing in between.ldquoThis has been raised a number of times with the council, but it falls on deaf ears.ldquoThey are quite happy for visitors to be paying pound, but you canrsquot always walk from the car park for a coffee within an hour.ldquoThis is why car parking is a problem ndash because the charges are unfair.ldquoSomething needs to be done.Marco Zeraschi, of Marcorsquos Cafeacute, said: ldquoIrsquove always been an advocate of a multi-storey car park on Harbour Road.ldquoJust donrsquot put a brick building up or something sterile.ldquoDress it to make it look like a ship or a sail or something like that which would blend in with the seaside.ldquoDress it so it doesnrsquot look like an eyesore from outside the Island as well ndash it could be something special there, iconic.ldquoYou could do wonderful things with some good imagination.ldquoThe Nellrsquos Point car park is still up for development andwe lose that yoursquove lost over  car parking spaces.ldquoWe need an extra  never mind .ldquoIf you multi-storey the Harbour Road one there would be a vast improvement and you would have control over it to stop the boy racers at night.ldquoAnd it would make money for the Valethey had , spaces.He added: ldquoIf residents think theyrsquove got it bad now, the residents of the West End of Barry will have it as well.Vale town and Barry Town Council Baruc ward councillors, Nic Hodges and Steffan Wiliam reiterated their call for a multi-storey car park on the Old Harbour site.Cllr Hodges said: ldquoWith the increasing popularity of the island as a tourist destination, we must ensure it can cope with increased visitor numbers without detrimentally affecting residents.ldquoOur persistent call for resident parking on streets title: outdoor events trialled wales easing lockdown
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe trials are part of further changes to coronavirus regulations announced by first minister, Mark Drakeford.Indoor visits to care homes will also be allowed from Saturday, August , subject to the strict controls set out in the guidance and conditions remaining favourable.However, the first minister emphasised that theof pupils to schools and colleges from September  is the top priority during this  day regulation cycle.The Welsh Government recognises the value of the events sector to Wales and how cultural, sports and business events are a vital part of the visitor economy and one of the last sectors left to re-open.Initially three small events, with limits of up to  people, and subject to strict risk assessments, will be held across Wales later this month.Outdoor events are being prioritised in this review period, while the weather is mild, due to evidence of lower transmission of coronavirus outdoors.If these small events can be carried out safely, and transmission of the virus remains low, it is hoped the next stage will be increased numbers of participants, allowing a limited number of spectators to attend sporting events and potentially considering trialling small scale business events.In the coming weeks three small scale events will be trialled to inform future review processes.Outdoor events of up to  people include Theatr Clwydrsquos proposals for a number of live outdoor performances from August,  Welsh Triathlonrsquos planned lsquoReturn to Racingrsquo competition at Pembrey Country Park which will be a closed venue and without spectators and a car rally at Anglesey Circuit Trac Mon Race track.The Welsh Government continues to work closely with the UK Government to monitor the outcomes from the trials that have taken place recently.Mr Drakeford also confirmed that from Saturday, August , extended households can expand to include up to four households in an exclusive, extended arrangement.From the same day, weddings and funerals will be able to include a meal for up to  people, in suitably socially distant settings.Subject to the successful resumption of weddings and funerals, it is hoped to further increase the range of indoor ceremonies allowed in the next review period, including christenings, baptisms and bar mitzvahs.Casinos will be allowed to reopen from Saturday, August , provided they follow the guidance available to them.Mr Drakeford said: ldquoWhile coronavirus remains effectively suppressed in Wales and cases continue to fall, the situation in the rest of the UK and further afield is still problematic."Coronavirus has not gone away and so, as we move out of lockdown and look to the future, it is important we do this in a careful and cautious way.ldquoWe appreciate how hard it has been for families not seeing their loved ones and the impact restrictions on visiting care homes is having on peoplersquos emotional, mental and even physical health.ldquoIn an effort to address this we have been working closely with partners and intend to allow indoor visits to care homes to recommence from Saturday, August , subject to the strict controls set out in the guidance and conditions remaining favourable.ldquoIn addition we will trial three small scale events, in partnership with the events organisers, local authorities and other stakeholders, to seethey can be carried out in a safe way, with a view to supporting the sector and making the most of the remaining summer months where we can spend time outdoors.ldquoWe will also learn from pilots being conducted across the UK, in reopening professional sport and indoor theatre to supporters and audiences, so we base our decisions on the best possible evidence available."We will continue to talk with event organisers about the possible resumption of some other activities later in the autumn.ldquoBut, for the time being, we need to learn from how we can safely hold outdoor events while maintaining social distancing.ldquoWe will use the next three weeks to continue to engage with those remaining sectors of our economy that remain affected by coronavirus restrictions."I would like to thank the sector representatives for the way they continue to engage, coming out of lockdown will always be harder than going into it - but, together, we will do it in the safest possible way.From  September, schools and further education colleges willfrom the summer break, and will teach pupils through a iety of ways, either in the classroom or remotely.The First Minister added:ldquoTheof pupils is the most signicant important activity which will take place in Wales during the next  days and most of the headroom we have is being devoted to making this a success.ldquoIt is critical that we get children back into schools in the safest possible way. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentGAVIN  Stacey was based in Barry after Little Britain star Matt Lucas provided the foot in the door for people unfamiliar with James Corden.That was the situation, location manager Clive Evans, has revealed while he was scouting for places in which the award-winning could be based.And Weston-super-Mare could have masqueraded as lsquoWalesrsquoBarry hadnrsquot won the production companyrsquos heart.Freelance Location manager, Clive Evans, whose projects also include The Bill The Story of Tracey Beaker Doctor Who Very Annie Mary, Young Dracula You Get Me and As If, used Mr Lucas as an ice-breaker as James Corden, in , was relatively unknown and Mr Lucas was featuring in the new series.MORE STORIESGavin and Stacey fans flock to Barry Island to catch sight of the locationsSupporters who helped make Gavin  Stacey happen in BarryThe Gavin and Stacey effect -  years onMr Evans, of Cardigan in West Wales, but now living in Brecon, said: ldquoIrsquod taken a call back in  to check my availability for a small comedy for BBC Three and set in South Wales.ldquoI met up with Christine Gernonand Ruth Jonesat the Castell Mynach pub near Llantrisant one afternoon to discuss the script and the locations they wanted me to scout.ldquoAn hour or so after the meeting, I got the call from the production company Baby Cow offering me the job.ldquoMy first task was to sit with Dave Ferrisand discuss the vision for Gavin  Staceyrsquos backdrop and get a feel for the key locations.ldquoStaceyrsquos hometown was scripted as a South Wales coastal town, but I was given a free run on this so the hunt took me to Aberavon, Porthcawl, Tenby, Saundersfoot, and Weston-super-Mare - a cheatit had been suitable.ldquoBack in  there were a few areas in Barry which were beginning to look a little tired, but it also came with a timeless charm that provided us with the perfect texture and feel that Dave and I had discussed.ldquoAdded to this was the welcome we were given by residents and, in particular, the support of the local council.ldquoPorthcawl was also a serious candidate for the backdrop to this show, but having scouted tirelessly the whole of Barry and Barry Island, I knew that this ticked every box.Mr Evans said Trinity Street was an instant favourite.ldquoI knew Gwenrsquos house was here, he said. ldquoThe terraced houses on a steep hill and its far-reaching views over to Barry Island and docks meant that no matter which direction the camera was pointing, there would be interesting textures and views.ldquoThe next objective was to get inside as many houses as possible to seeany worked for us as Gwenrsquos house.ldquoI letter dropped about  houses to gauge the interest.ldquoIrsquod heard that Matt Lucas was going to be involved so I used his name get to my foot in the door.ldquoThis usually helps.ldquoIn those days very few had heard of James Corden.ldquoI viewed and took pictures of about five houses on that street and Glendarsquos who was one of the first to contact me.ldquoThe decor and character of Glendarsquos house fitted my brief perfectly, but my first thought was that house was a little on the small side.ldquoTo get a film crew and the actors to work in such a tight space would be quite a challenge, butI could convince our director and designer that it could be achieved Gwenrsquos house was found.ldquoI took Dave and Christine along to Trinity Street and both fell in love with the location within minutes.Mr Evans continued: ldquoGlenda was so accommodating.ldquoI remember very well discussing with her the details of how filming on location works, how disruptive the whole process can be and also the location fee.ldquoWhat I do remember was her reaction when I mentioned the amount.ldquoGlendarsquos reply was: ldquoIrsquom so sorry Clive, but I donrsquot think I can cover that.ldquoGlenda thought that she needed to pay for the privilege of having us there and not the other way round.ldquoShe is a lovely lady and still loves being a part of the Gavin  Stacey world.During the locationsrsquo breakdown meeting, we discussed how Pam and Mickrsquos house might look in Billericay so homes were viewed in and around Llandaff and Sully until Dinas Powys was selected thanks to the welcome that was received.ldquoSt Cattwgrsquos Church at Llanmaes was not the first-choice wedding venue for Gavin and Stacey, Mr Evans said. ldquoThey were due to be married at St Nicholas Church at the village of St Nicholas, but a last-minute change of heart by the Church in Wales meant that we needed to find an alternative at the th hour.ldquoA friend and another locations manager called Chris Hill pulled in a favour and we were able to use St Cattwgrsquos.ldquoI dont recall any candidates other than Island Leisure .ldquoWhile filming on the front, Marco opening up early for the crew to be able to get a nice coffee as the weather was pretty unkind.ldquoWe didnt use the interior of the coffee shop as a location in series one, but as it was so cold when we filmed on the seafront the coffees were very welcome.ldquoWe also filmed at the Vale of Glamorgan Resort for the exterior of the wedding fair.ldquoThe interior was shot at the Copthorne Hotel at Culverhouse Cross.ldquoWhile at the Vale resort, the Wales rugby team came into the reception of the hotel.ldquoRuth Jones askedIrsquod be able to set up a photograph of the cast with the Welsh team.ldquoWe got them to agree so out there somewhere are pictures of the Gavin  Stacey cast with the Wales rugby team.ldquoUncle Brynrsquos house was only an exterior in series one so very little was involved in its search.ldquoQuiz night at the Colcot Arms was interesting.ldquoWe were close to completing our filming when the pub opened to the public - so the last few shots took a little while longer than wersquod planned.Mr Evans lives with his we Rhiannon and daughter Cerys Mim and runs his own Film and TV Facilities company.He added: ldquoThe actors usually donrsquot get to see the locations beforehand.ldquoThey are brought to set, run through a quick rehearsal then go for the real thing.ldquoThey then have to go through the whole thing over and over with the camera shooting from dferent angles.ldquoIt is a slow process and  hours on camera gives us around three minutes of footage.ldquoI get a real buzz from seeing locations that I have found on TV, but when it comes to Gavin  Stacey the story I always bring up is that while scouting in the very early days with the series producer in the car he askedI would consider reading for Dave.ldquoMy le could have been so dferent, but I have no regrets as no-one could have played it better than Steffan Rhodri.ldquoMy daughter Cerys Mim was born during filming and James Corden was the first to congratulate me when I ed to work on the show after her birth.ldquoHe joked about us naming her Nessa or Stacey.ldquoBarry and the Vale have always provided me with a fantastic hunting ground for film and TV locations.ldquoIts a huge contributor to South Wales becoming a hotspot for filming in the last decade or so. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: lockdown led likely dinosaur footprints discovery penarth beach
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe markings, embedded in a section of rock at the beach, are still being investigated by researchers at NHM, and nothing has been confirmed at this stage.NHM scientists say they do not yet know which dinosaur the prints belong to.On a sunny dayon April , Ms Rees, who had been furloughed from her role as a youth worker at Challenge Wales, came across the site on her morning stroll.Pictures: Kerry ReesShe saidit wasnt for lockdown, she wouldnt have even been in Penarth at the time."Im from Penarth but moved to the Rhondda, and was only in Penarth to look after my mother during the pandemic," she said."I had an idea it could be evidence of a dinosaur. I knew the areahad a history of dinosaur discoveries along this coastline."I didnt have much to do in lockdown and decided to take it further and send them to the NHM. I only started to get excited when they informed me they were very interested in the photos."Im trying to not get too excited yet though, as it is still under investigation - Im not totally sure how it has all come out this morning.Pictures: Patrick Wagstaff"If they turn out to be genuine footprints, then of course its very exciting for the area."If confirmed, they would be the third set of dinosaur tracks in Wales and a huge boost to the areas archaeological heritage, according to researchers.Professor Paul Barrett, Merit Researcher at the NHM, said: "Were pretty convinced that these are dinosaur tracks but are aware there are other geological processes that can create track-like features.Weve just started our work on the site so hope to have a definite answer soon."Kerry found a series of large indentations on the beach - these are deep, round in outline and bear many of the hallmarks of dinosaur tracks, as they seem to be regularly spaced and have raised mud rims like those that form as a foot pushes into wet mud or sand."Dr Susannah Maidment, another researcher working on the project, added: "The rocks that these possible tracks are preserved in date from the Late Triassic period so,were right, theyre among some of the oldest evidence of dinosaurs in the UK."Other trackways of similar age, and one good dinosaur skeleton, have been found a few miles along the coast, near Barry, so south Wales was a busy area for dinosaurs at the time." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: Car destroyed in arson attackMissing person - Gordie WalkerNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsCall for temporary driving test centre for CraigavonLearner drivers from Craigavon can no longer take driving tests locally as the DVA at Carn is being used as a COVID- test centre.By Carmel RobinsonTuesday, th August , : am""As the first driving tests since Lockdown begin on September , concerns have been raised that those from Craigavon will be unable to avail of this facility.A number of local politicians have voiced concern that those from Craigavon may be disadvantaged and Sinn Fein has called fora a temporary driving test facility to be set up.Upper Bann MP Carla Lockhart and DUP Cllrs Margaret Tinsley and Tim McClelland urged Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon MLA to reintroduce driver testing at Craigavon immediately, after local motorists were informed that tests would have to be undertaken at other centres – including Lisburn and Armagh.Mrs Lockhart said: “This situation is untenable and places local motorists at a distinct disadvantage be it for driving, trailer and HGV tests.“This week I have received representation from each of the sectors that use Craigavon and they are very distressed about the impact it will have on their respective businesses.Some of these sectors are the main supply for our haulage and agricultural industry. “Craigavon Test Centre covers a very wide geographical area and is one of the busiest centres in Northern Ireland with a large number of tests being conducted every year,” said Mrs Lockhart who said she took comfort in taking her test on roads she knew. “That is a comfort that will not be available to local learner drivers who are taking their driving test. That is unfair. “I have raised this with the Minister and asked her to urgently review this decision and to quickly reinstate these test.I have requested a meeting with her so that the instructors can highlight their concerns.”Sinn Féin MLA John O’Dowd called for the opening of temporary driving test facility in Craigavon while the normal center is used for Covid  testing.Mr O’Dowd said: “While I welcome the commencement of Driving Tests across the North I have to express my disappoint they will not be recommencing in Craigavon. I understand the use of the current center for Covid  testing rules out this facility however other facilities could be used to keep tests in the Craigavon area.“I have written to Minister Mallon and asked for other options to be explored and another venue identied to allow learner drivers to complete their tests.”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. welcomed by DUP and SFArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s event to celebrate the th anniversary of VJ Day has been welcomed by both the DUP and Sinn Fein.By The NewsroomThursday, th August , : pm""Council has confirmed a shared history event to mark the occasion will take place this Saturday, August .Many local people were heldas Japanese prisoners of war and the stories of their experience still haunt the families to this day.The event will include a lecture from renowned historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, poetry reading by local historian Richard Edgar and a musical accompaniment from piper Ian Burrows.Speaking about the event, Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage said: “Shared history events are important for a ided society.“We hope that by embracing social media and digital technology we can attract wider audiences comprised of people who – for ious reasons – might not normally attend such an event in person.“With COVID- still very much a concern at the moment, we are hoping to run more online events like these to ensure we’re minimising the risk to our residents while still offering the excellent events we’re known for, albeit in a slightly dferent way.”DUP group whip Councillor Darryn Causby said it was important for Council to mark the occasion, widely regarded as the end of the second World War.“It is important for Council to mark this occasion,” he said.“We are obviously disappointed that it could not be marked in a more substantial way than what we are doing.“However, we welcome the fact all parties recognise the vital role the British Army played during the second World War and we welcome that across the piece.”Speaking about ABC Council’s shared history event SinnFein group leader, Councillor Liam Mackle said: “Many local people lost their lives in this conflict.“The Lord Mayor will pay special tribute to local man Jim Haughey. Jim fought against fascismin the International Brigade in the Spanish Civil War and was later killed in .“Council officers deserve special praise for organising this event which was inclusive and contributed to our shared understanding of history.”Initially proposed by DUP group leader, Councillor Mark Baxter duringthe course of July’s full council meeting, the idea to hold a socially distanced event compliant with COVID regulations was put to a vote following a fiery debate.In total,  members voted for the proposal with the DUP, UUP, Alliance Party and IndependentCouncillorPaul Berry in support of the proposal.The five SDLP members present abstained and the nine Sinn Fein members present voted against the proposal.The event will be broadcast on Council’s facebook page from -.am on Saturday, August . title: post primary pupils now to wear face coverings in corridors
story: Education Minister Peter Weir has announced that guidance on face coverings will be updated to include wearing them in corridors of post-primary schools. This will come into effect on  August when schoolson a full-time basis. The Minister said: “My key priority is that pupilsto school on a full-time basis, as soon as it is safe to do so. “Following further advice which I have received today from the Chief Medical Officer and the Chief Scientic Adviser, I am recommending that pupils and teachers wear a face covering in corridors and other communal areas of post-primary schools from next week when schoolsfull-time. This updates the existing guidance on the use of face coverings in educational settings. “The current public health advice is that the use of face coverings provides some benefits, however, it is not a replacement for frequent hand washing, social distancing where possible, covering your mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze and regular cleaning of surfaces. It is also important to remember that evidence suggests that the risk of transmission in schools is relatively low compared to some other settings. “My existing guidance on the reopening of schools already deals with the use of face coverings. In terms of school transport, the advice remains the same, that we strongly recommend that all pupils wear a face covering on all dedicated school transport including buses and taxis where it is appropriate for them to do so. “In relation to communal areas in schools, the guidance already strongly encourages face coverings for activities that entail large numbers of staff or pupils within an enclosed space where social distancing is not possible. “Given the risk mitigations in place in schools to limit and contain the spread of Covid-, face coverings are not recommended as being compulsory for routine use in education settings. However, staff and pupils may wish to use them during the routine school day and this is acceptable. Schools should also be aware that some personsare exempt from wearing face coverings. “I will continue to keep all guidance in respect of education settings under review in light of the latest medical and scientic advice. Peter Weir said: “The first step in keeping our schools safe is that anyone with symptoms should not attend school. Parents should not send their children to schoolthey have any of the Covid- symptoms including: a high temperature a new, continuous cough a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste.” The
